content: Speaking of which, we should talk about another hackathon! I totally lost the plot, though, and I have to catch up
YES!
YES!

Let's plan this -- maybe for April? I've been working on some thoughts about a-mir-formality that may be a kind of radical change (i.e., going back to a place where the type checker has the role of computing regions), but I have to bottom them out, I hope to do that over next week or two.

it would be very interesting to hear more about this.

let's see if @Amanda Stjerna @Dylan MacKenzie (ecstatic-morse) @Domenic Quirl @lengyijun and others would like that and if they have availability ?
I’d like to hang around for the update but I can’t promise to deliver anything concrete

Hi all :wave:
The break since the last time we met makes me a bit worried I'll ask half of my previous questions again, but I'm always interested to hear more ideas. So I'd definitely try to make time available - it feels like I've just recently gotten to the point where my out-of-work time is not all taken up
by moving and organizing and getting my new home set up anymore, so there are reasons to be carefully optimistic. That said I probably won't be able to make our previous meeting time (at least, if time zones/summer time doesn't help me out here), since it's unrealistic that I'm back from work in time.

Also, did y'all have/make plans for how to move forward in the meantime? I tried to skim over most things, but had to wait for a few weeks to get the apartment connected up to the Internet so you've probably had some discussions I've missed (also I think I saw that there was a video meeting? which obviously I kinda haven't read up on ^^)

I'm around as well, although I've not been on Zulip at all. I've been doing some Lean and enjoying post-Omicron, pre-BA.2 life here in the States.

To sum up from my POV for Domenic Quirl, I did a bit of research into type systems with subtyping constraints (for<'a, 'b> where 'a : 'b fn (&'a &'b)) (see "Type Inference with Constrained Types") and implemented a toy solver for some of the subtyping constraints we have in Rust (it doesn't break down functions yet).

It seemed like the next logical step was to integrate this into Chalk, but I wasn't detecting much enthusiasm for this type of thing. Maybe I went wrong somewhere? IIRC, Chalk didn't have a way of distinguishing between existentially and universally quantified lifetime/type variables in the way that I needed. Even if I loaded this all back into cache, I would likely need a lot of help from @nikomatsakis or @Jack Huey to even get started, and I figured the traits team has other, more pressing stuff on their plate. That said, it seems Polonius is on the roadmap for 2024, so maybe nikomatsakis has more time to devote to it?

Also, it seems like the "core" of Polonius is maybe less settled than I had first though. .next sort of came out of nowhere (I was hoping to do more implementation than ideation, despite the above paragraph), and it seems like there may be more changes in the pipeline. I'm not sure how useful I would be for that. Frankly, I didn't contribute much to the .next discussions.

At some point I wrote the frontend of an in-memory, Rust-native Datalog engine with the hopes that we could write future analyses passes in it. I love Souffle, but it has a very poor FFI interface and some of the more advanced features (aggregates) are buggy. I might try to finish that if I get back into Rust. I've learned that, if I'm going to work for free :sweat_smile: , I want to do it in my own repo, or at least one that doesn't require reviewer sign-off before being merged upstream. I feel bad taking up reviewer time, and I find the delays and rebasing demoralizing.
@Dylan MacKenzie (ecstatic-morse) we definitely need to talk about subtyping
I've got a scheme for "more or less exactly that"
that I'm feeling pretty ok about it
it's implemented in a-mir-formality, though I'm still testing and extending it...
it also covers outlives relations
that part is not yet implemented :)
and I believe it should work with associated types
("alias types")
which are an extra bundle of joy
i've not though about const generics yet though :)

nikomatsakis said:

it's implemented in a-mir-formality, though I'm still testing and extending it...

I'm reading the doc from wg-traits now... Very excited about this!!!
